labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

comments.body: Why are all of these under "informative" references? Informative references are used in explanations of use cases and applications. They are not supposed to describe how to implement parts of a standard. The ones listed below also seem essential to describing the standard, so they should be normative references. Perhaps just replace the current "normative" references with these references and leave "informative" empty.
Done.
We're not using [OHTTP].
Done.

```suggestion
title: Protected Audience Key Value Services
```

```suggestion
abbrev: "KV Services"
```
Hmm should we change "server-api" to "services" here and in the file name and in README.md?

```suggestion
Key Value Services are used by Protected Audience to provide
real-time signals to buyers and sellers during ad selection.
```

```suggestion
services to incorporate real-time signals into ad selection.
```

```suggestion
These services utilize User-Defined Functions (UDFs) to
```

```suggestion
-   The core request and response data is encoded using [CBOR].
```

```suggestion

To understand this document, it is important to know that the
communication between the client and the remote services uses a
request-response message exchange pattern.
```

```suggestion
On a high level, these request and response messages adhere to the following communication protocol:
```

```suggestion
The request/response is framed with this 5 byte header.
```

```suggestion
Before encryption and after decryption, the requests and responses have the following framing:
```
I think we should use some bits to specify a version number, like B&A does.

```suggestion
The first byte is the format+compression byte. The lower 2 bits specify the format and compression.
The higher 6 bits are currently unused.
```
This should link to the #compression section.
This should link to the #padding section.
Can we link this to the definition of acceptCompression?

Can we move this sentence into another section?  I don't think it makes sense to have a one sentence section. 
 Preferably move it alongside where we specify how padding is done, like line 127.
I think we need to explain or link to definitions of "interest group" and "joining site" here.
Can we link "See more details below" to the details?
if "none" is a string, we should put quotes around none, gzip, and brotli
Should the response have the response media type? not request?
updated
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
I'd like to resolve this for now and if we do decide to add it, I'll do that in a follow-up
I feel like we should link to the Protected Audience spec

```suggestion
real-time signals to buyers and sellers during auctions performing ad selection.
```
Should this also link to the PA spec?

```suggestion
Structured keys are keys that the client is aware of and the client
can use the response to do
additional processing. The value of these keys must abide by the
following schema for the client to
```

```suggestion
    ; A list of supported response compression algorithms; must contain at least one of "none", "gzip", "brotli"
```

```suggestion
    ; Unique id of the partition in this request. Used by responses to refer to request partitions.
```
I don't feel I contributed enough to be listed as an author here. Lusa, do you want to put yourself here?
What are real-time signals? What are ad auctions? The abstract can be longer than a sentence and should provide a description of what the standard is about that can be understood without any context.
define real-time signals. What sort of use cases (rate limiting, creative approval, etc)?

The definition of media types here is confusing. It might be better to move the description of media types to where they are actually used for the Request and Response. Then you can demonstrate how they are intended to be used.

"a set of pre-configured lengths" - What are these lengths?
Also, you may want to delegate descriptions of padding for requests and responses to subsections in the description of requests and responses.

>Padding is applied with sizes as multiples of 2^n KBs ranging from 0 to 2MB.

This is for the response?
What happens when the response doesn't fit in 2MB?

```
|    0x03     | Reserved                            |
```

> For requests, the byte value is 0x00

Does that mean that requests are always uncompressed? Can we just say that - "Requests are always uncompressed so the Format+compression byte is 0x00"
What do you mean by "Core" here?

> Keys from one interest
    group must be in the same partition. Keys from different interest groups with the same joining
    site (see https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/#joining-interest-groups) may or may not be in the same partition.

I'm not sure this is necessary. It should be up to the client to decide how to partition keys when it assembles a request

>Each partition is a collection of keys that can be processed together

Probably should be "Each partition is a collection of keys that SHALL be processed together"

We also probably don't need "without any potential privacy leakage". We may also want to add "Keys from separate partitions MUST NOT be processed together by the service." Then we could add a reference to the Security Considerations section where we can say that "Using separate partitions allow clients to break up the request to achieve desired privacy goals, such as preventing keys from an interest group joined on one origin from influencing the response for keys from an interest group joined on another origin".
We could also add a reference here to the Security Considerations section describing why we need separate compression groups.
Can we be more explicit here? I'd rather err on the side of being too explicit. In the B&A spec I wrote the procedure for encryption in a similar section to this.
Instead of `tstr` as the type you should use a new type defined as `"none" / "gzip" / "brotli"`. That makes it explicit that this is a string enum.

What is `trustedBiddingSignalsSlotSizeMode`? It's not defined in this document. Either omit it or reference the field in the Protected Audience spec (https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/#dom-generatebidinterestgroup-trustedbiddingsignalsslotsizemode)
That also seems to get into how a client might use the protocol instead of a description of the protocol.
descripten -> described
The method for de-encapsulation and decryption are not specified in this spec. You should describe in more detail either here or in the relevant section.
By de-encapsulation and decryption you seem to just mean decrypting not removing the framing. We should probably be more explicit about this.
For requests the only supported compression is "none", correct?
How do you handle decoding errors? Also, do you require deterministic CBOR? Are there any other requirements?
What about handling fields? Are there scenarios where you would throw an error - like a compression group with no partitions, or too many partitions? What about missing fields?

Let's emphasize that this is an example. "An example of the [CBOR] representation using the extended diagnostic notation from [CDDL] Appendix G" (also link "Appendix G" to the actual Appendix G here).

In general, examples should go in the Appendices since they are non-normative.
Again, I'm not sure what "Core" means here.
"The response is compressed" is not technically true for compression scheme "None".

This paragraph feels like it belongs in {{response-schema}}.

Here we should probably have something describing a high level view of the responses - "An HPKE encrypted message sent as a Response to a Request, containing a framed top-level CBOR encoded payload that itself can contain multiple, possibly compressed, CBOR encoded messages."
Be more explicit here as well.

It's better to name things:
```
compressionGroup = [* partitionOutput]
```

This is more of a question about the response format than the spec itself. Why do we have a dictionary containing a single string field instead of just putting the string field directly? It make be good to have a comment about this here in case someone asks.
Move examples to Appendices.
Examples go in Appendices.
Use a different prefix for one of them. That makes it clear that they don't have to be "signal#"
This is not correct. We can't compress the top-level response. That leaves us open to compression ratio side-channel attacks (something to also mention in security considerations).
It might be more natural to start with key-value responses to one or more partitions and compression groups. It feels like we're starting from the half-way point instead of the beginning.

Add Security Considerations section.

Also IANA Considerations will likely include the new HTTP media types to be used with HTTP "content-type" headers (if specified in this spec).

+1 to what Russ said, perhaps something like "This document specifies a protocol for a service that can serve data with low latency and no side effects.  The data served can be used by clients for advertisement selection and the lack of side effects can be used to advance user privacy."
I think we need to define TEE before we use the term.

Words  from https://developers.google.com/privacy-sandbox/private-advertising/protected-audience
```suggestion
[Protected Audience](https://wicg.github.io/turtledove/) is a privacy advancing API that serves
remarketing and custom audiences use cases.
```

```suggestion
into ad selection for both buyers and sellers. These services provide a
```

```suggestion
is explicitly prohibited, the services may have operational side effects like
```
I think we should link HTTPS to the appropriate specification

I find this really hard to understand.  I don't understand how each key group is "unique".  What is unique about it? is this a requirement of the key group or just something the client does?
I don't understand what the "tags" are for.  I think we need some motivation.
I don't understand what it means "to look up" a key.  Can we explain what this means and what it is looked up in?
Why?  How is this used?
I think we need to introduce the term interest group before using it.  Perhaps describe it as "an identifier of information about a user collected on a particular website or application".

Are these picked from the below list of "Available Tags"?  If so, we should link to that section.
If this is an enumeration, we should declare its possible values rather than use the type "tstr" I think like Russ mentioned above for `acceptCompression`

trustedBiddingSignalsKeys needs a definition, which is going to be very complicated.  Perhaps it's better to give some more general description like `"keys" represent the keys to be used to look up values in a table` or something that ties back to the "to look up" mention above.

I don't know what "Similarly" is referring similarity to.
It's unclear how "sellers may want to fetch information about a specific creative" relates to renderUrls.
trustedScoringSignalsUrl needs a definiition, which is going to be very complicated.  Perhaps its better to give a more general description like `"renderUrls" represent URLs for advertisements that are used to look up values in a table`
This needs more description.
Sure, I'll add Tianyang too.
Done.
Done.
Moved to other section.
Moved it to different sections so it's clearer.
Done.
@peiwenhu how do we want to handle large responses?
Done.
Done.
Will do.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
@peiwenhu I don't remember exactly why we had it like this. Do you?
Done.
Done.
Thanks for catching that.
Done.
Done. Will start a doc on that.
@peiwenhu are we prescribing that it is from the list of available tags? I don't think we should, since this will be input to the UDF.
Done.
Removed that
Right, fixed it.
Changed the wording.
Done.

"Different compression groups must be compressed separately..." That's referring to the response, but from the context it could refer to the request.

So maybe something like:
"The responses for different compression groups will be compressed separately in the response (see {{compression-group}}). Compressing the different groups separately avoids leaking the similarity of responses for different groups."
The client needs to save `sctxt`.
Should the schema specify that at least one "partitions" is required (e.g. `partitions: [1* partition]`)?
`compressionGroupid` -> `compressionGroupId`
In the schema, the `id` and `compressionGroupId` fields are required in the request.  It seems unusual to check for the presence of a required field.
What does the server do if the response does not fit in 2MB?
What data type is `payload`?
Should this field be required? I'm not sure what a partitionOutput without an ID would mean.

Maybe clearer to rewrite as "Set `partition output map[partition id]` to `partitionOutput`. Also consider renaming `partition output map` to not have spaces - either `partition_output_map` or `partitionOutputMap`.
What is the type of `compression group`?
Add -> Append?
It doesn't have to be GZIP though. Maybe we should specify at the top that this response is to a request that included "gzip" as one of the acceptable compressions.
So on compression failure, we send an empty message field instead of omitting it entirely? It seems like we should just skip the entire compression group.
`framing header` -> `framed payload`.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
@peiwenhu
Done.
Done.
This is technically not correct, actually. Keeping it as is.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
Done.
It returns an error response code. in the future the response code can be inside the ciphertext once we have error handling defined.
Are you going to specify the "preconfigured lengths" here? If not, you might just want to say that "Messages MAY be zero padded".
It sounds like there are different types of tags: `namespace` tags and other unspecified tags. Can you describe this more explicitly?
So the values in `compressionGroupMap` are...itself? Shouldn't it be a list of partitions?

You may want to specify how the Key Value Service creates the "partitionOutputs"
 - as the output from the UDF given the keys (and what other fields) in the corresponding input
 - describe constraints on UDF?
Thanks, added a short paragraph on UDFs.
Thanks for catching that. The values should be a list of partition Ids.
It looks like we've updated the API spec to drop namespace. Updated it.
Done.
Discussed offline, we don't really want to restrict it to only those tags.

pulls.title: Add request generating and response parsing sections
pulls.author: xtlsheep

comments.body: Should we be setting `partition["id"]` to `compression group id` here? Otherwise all the partitions will have an ID of 0.
The framing header doesn't have a Version field. Do you mean "Compression"?

You could probably combine these cases to something like:

Set `serialized content` to the result of decompressing `group["content"]` according to the compression algorithm specified in the `framing header`'s `Compression` field, returning failure if decompression fails.
You're not doing anything with the partition IDs or compression IDs here. I think those are necessary in order to map the response back to the request.

Gotcha, this request generation part will be updated to a new version that takes a list of compression group, which has a list of partitions, and use counters to assign compression group id and partition id. Will let you know after the new patch is uploaded.
Yeah, changed it to `Compression`.
Done.
Added compression group id and partition id to the output result map.

I'm having trouble parsing what `compression groups` list looks like. What do you mean by "from key `"partitions"` to value `partitions`? I don't see a definition from either type, and I'm not sure what the quote characters in `"partitions`" indicate.
You're looping over `compression groups` and then over a field in  `compression groups`. It seems like that would give you all combinations of both, which is probably not what you want.
As discussed, this is a typo here. Changed `compression groups` to `group`.
As discussed, updated the description of input arguments, and add a new field "namespace" in the partition struct.

We better not copy each tag blindly. We should look through each tag in [2.2.3.1](https://privacysandbox.github.io/draft-ietf-protected-audience-key-value-service/draft-ietf-protected-audience-key-value-services.html#section-2.2.3.1) so that we only extract recognized tags. Otherwise it may be a problem if we add new tag types.

Return `request` and `request context`.
(add missing space)
Add a if case to check if the tag is one of those available tags.
Done
I still think it is cleaner to loop through the available tags and then see if the tag exists, but I guess this works as well.

I wonder if you also want to indicate here that this is an example that only is looking to accept no compression or gzip (0 or 2), which is why it checks for 0 or 2. 

Or you may want to change the language from "Client MUST" to "Client MAY". Otherwise it makes it seem like all clients MUST reject compression bit 1.
But don't we want to reject the the responses with compression bit as 1 for now?
Oh, for now, yes. We can update this later then.

```suggestion
    1. Set `p["compressionGroupId"]` to `group["compressionGroupId"]`.
```
I don't think this should be an HTTP reference, but should instead be a reference to #tags or perhaps {{Available Tags}}

```suggestion
a `compressionGroupID` and one or more `partition`s. Each `partition`
```
I'm not sure if I'm using the right quotes, but I think we need to make this match the steps below
I don't think we should say "such as" if they're required, which according to the steps below it looks like they are.

```suggestion
compression group structs. Each compression group struct contains
```
I don't think we should say "includes multiple keys" as this is not very definitive or specific.  I'd say it's a struct with some required fields, or it's a map with specific key and value types.

```suggestion
"metadata", whose value is a map where both keys and values are strings;
and "namespace", whose value is a map where keys are strings and values
```

```suggestion
It takes as input the `request context`, returned from
{{request-generate}}, and an `encrypted response`, an array of bytes from the Key Value Service generated by {{Generating a Response}}.
```
I don't know if I'm using the right syntax here.
Changed to `compression group id` which represents the value of partition["compressionGroupId"].
Changed to "which contain"

Changed this sentence to
```
Each `partition` is a map with specified keys, which are "id," ...
```

```suggestion
This algorithm takes as input:
* an [HPKE] `public key`.
* a `key id` integer associated with `public key`.
* a `metadata` map for global configuration, where both keys and
values are strings.
* a `compression groups`, which is a list of `group`s, each
with the following parameters:
 * a `compressionGroupId` integer identifier of this compression
   group.
 * a `partitions`, which is a list of `partition`s belonging to this compression
   group. Each `partition` has the following parameters:
   * an `id` integer identifier of this partition.
   * a `namespace` map whose keys are strings and values are list of
     strings.
   * a `metadata` map whose keys and values are strings.
```

pulls.title: Include clear text http headers in spec
